text.p: Sales in Chile's machinery and metallurgical sector rose a mere 1.7 percent in the first seven months of 1996, over the same period last year, the trade group Asimet reported.
The surprisingly small increase was the latest sign of a slowdown in Chilean economic growth this year.
Lower international prices for steel also contributed to the paucity of the rise, said the president of Asimet, Hermann von Muhlenbrock.
Production by volume in the whole sector rose 2.5 percent in the first seven months of the year, with a declining rate of growth as of March, he told a news conference.

Basic metallic industrial sales posted a decline of six percent in the first seven months of the year, while sales in the combined category of metallic products, machinery and equipment rose 9.7 percent, said von Muhlenbrock.

The economy is expected to grow about seven percent for all of 1996, with most expansion posted early in the year as restrictive Central Bank policies have taken a bite out of growth after the first quarter, economists have said.
Growth has been concentrated in a few large industries, particularly copper mining and construction, a recent Central Bank report said.

In a sign of robust growth in construction, the Chilean Construction Chamber reported that employment in the building sector rose 8.4 percent in the May-to-July quarter over the same period last year.
